title: Oracles of Judgment
shortSummary: Isaiah 21 contains prophetic oracles concerning the impending judgment on Babylon, Dumah, and Arabia, revealing God's sovereign control over nations and His righteous judgment against sin and idolatry. The chapter uses vivid imagery and watchman symbolism to emphasize the certainty and imminence of divine justice.
timeline: c. 700 BC - During the Assyrian period, prior to the fall of Babylon

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and declares the visions and burdens concerning the nations.

keyCharacters.name: Watchman
keyCharacters.description: A symbolic figure set by God to observe and report the coming events of judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Elam
keyCharacters.description: A historical nation called to besiege Media as part of God's judgment plan.

keyCharacters.name: Media
keyCharacters.description: A nation allied with Elam, involved in the divine judgment against Babylon.

definitions.definition: A prophetic oracle or message, often of judgment, that the prophet is commissioned to deliver.
Idols or carved representations of gods, which are condemned as false and powerless.
A sentinel who observes and announces coming events, symbolizing prophetic vigilance.
A nomadic Arab tribe known for archers, representing the peoples of Arabia in this prophecy.

outline.heading: Oracle Against Babylon
outline.description: The chapter opens with a vivid vision of Babylon’s fall, describing the treachery and destruction that will come upon it, symbolized by a watchman’s report of the city’s collapse and the breaking of idols.

outline.heading: Oracle Concerning Dumah
outline.description: A brief dialogue between a caller and a watchman regarding the night and morning, symbolizing uncertainty and the coming day of judgment for the land of Dumah.

outline.heading: Oracle Against Arabia
outline.description: A prophecy against the Arabian tribes, particularly Dedanim and Kedar, forecasting their defeat and loss of glory within a year, emphasizing God’s sovereign judgment over all nations.

application: Remain vigilant in prayer and spiritual watchfulness, as God’s timing for judgment and deliverance is certain though often unseen.
Trust in God’s sovereignty over nations and history, knowing He will bring justice against idolatry and wickedness.
Respond to God’s warnings with repentance and faith, avoiding the treachery and rebellion that lead to destruction.
Encourage perseverance in the face of fear and uncertainty, relying on God’s promises and prophetic assurances.

keyVerses.text: And he answered and said, Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the graven images of her gods he hath broken unto the ground.
keyVerses.significance: This verse proclaims the definitive fall of Babylon and the futility of idolatry, highlighting God’s power to overthrow false gods.

keyVerses.text: For thus hath the Lord said unto me, Go, set a watchman, let him declare what he seeth.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the prophetic role as a watchman who must faithfully declare God’s warnings and revelations.

keyVerses.text: And the residue of the number of archers, the mighty men of the children of Kedar, shall be diminished: for the LORD God of Israel hath spoken it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the certainty of God’s decrees concerning the downfall of even powerful peoples like Kedar.
